fernebon.core.impl

Class ParticleListPartial<T extends Particle>

    • fernebon.core.impl.ParticleListPartial<T>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BosonListSimplePriority, ColliderListCollisionEventTypeMaskPriority, FermionListBitwiseSetUnions

extends java.lang.Object

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public void add(Emitter<T> emitter)
        "Adds" particle emitted by emitter to the lists etc.. Now: Nothing. When main changes applied: emitter.emitParticle method is called. Emitted particle has state set to MAIN_LIFE_STAGE and is actually added to the list(s) properly.
        Parameters:
        emitter -

      • addWithID

        public int addWithID(Emitter<T> emitter)

      • addWithID

        public int addWithID(int ID,
                     Emitter<T> emitter)
        See registerID. In particular, weird errors could be to do with methods here not checking if a positive ID is already registered, so if you have multiple places registering with the same ID, the last one is the one registered.
        Returns:
        The ID for the emitted element, which is only registered (and is automatically registered) once the element is added to internal list(s).

      • addWithPointer

        public Pointer<T> addWithPointer(Emitter<T> emitter)
        Returns:
        A pointer that is null and not registered until the element is added to the internal list(s). When that element is added, the pointer is automatically registered and pointed.

      • remove

        public void remove(T element)
        "Removes" element from lists etc.. Now: Life cycle state set to MARKED_FOR_REMOVAL. When main changes applied: Call dispose method, null pointers, and actually remove from the list(s) properly.

      • replace

        public void replace(T oldElement,
                    Emitter<T> newEmitter)
        "Replace" oldElement with one emitted by newEmitter. Now: State of old set to MARKED_FOR_REPLACEMENT. When main changes applied: Pointers re-pointed; call oldElement dispose method and remove from list(s); newElement is emitted, has state set to MAIN_LIFE_STAGE, and is actually added to the list(s) properly.

      • registerID

        public int registerID(T element)
        Registers the element for an automatically generated ID.
        Returns:
        The ID registered with element. ID<0.

      • registerID

        public int registerID(int ID,
                      T element)
        Registers the element with ID. Hard-coded IDs (ones specified by the programmer, like this ID) must be positive (negative is for auto-generated IDs, 0 is unused - if you have an ID of 0 stored somewhere, that variable may well be uninitialised.) Throws IllegalArgumentException if ID<=0. No check is made however as to whether ID is already registered - this could be a source of weird errors.
        Parameters:
        ID - Must have ID>0.
        Returns:
        ID.

      • reassignID

        public void reassignID(int ID,
                       T newElement)
        Sets which element is referred to by ID to newElement. ID must already be registered - if not, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.
        Parameters:
        ID - An already registered ID, so unlike registerID, this may be positive or negative (but it must still not be 0.)

      • deregisterID

        public void deregisterID(int ID)

      • newPointerFor

        public Pointer<T> newPointerFor(T particle)
        Returns a NEW pointer for the given particle. Doesn't check if the particle is in the list or not.
        Parameters:
        particle -
        Returns:

      • removePointer

        public void removePointer(Pointer<T> pointer)
        Removes all and any copies of the pointer from the internal list.
        Parameters:
        pointer -

      • get

        public <S extends T> S get(int ID)

      • contains

        public boolean contains(int ID)

      • particles

        public java.lang.Iterable<T> particles()

      • lock

        public void lock()
        Increase the number of locks by 1. A positive number of locks in place means changes are buffered, and all happen (order preserved) when the number of locks next fall to 0. You might want to do this to avoid issues like ConcurrentModification Exceptions, or issues with destroying B2D bodies during a physics step. Make sure you call unlock() when finished with the lock, but remember changes won't occur until the number of locks next falls to 0.

      • unlock

        public void unlock()
        Reduces the number of locks by 1. If that means there are now 0 locks, any buffered changes happen (order preserved). If instead there are now a negative number of locks, an IllegalStateException is thrown.

      • getLockCount

        public int getLockCount()
        Returns how many locks are in place. Changes happen instantly iff there are 0 locks. Only a non-negative number of locks is allowed, so remember to lock before unlocking.

      • failIfNotUnlocked

        public void failIfNotUnlocked()
        Throws an IllegalStateException if the list is not unlocked (so if lockCount!=0). Do this to fail "quickly" if there have not been as many unlocks as locks.

      • onDispose

        public void onDispose()
        The point of this is to dispose of all particles and any resources of the ParticleList. I think this effectively resets the ParticleListPartial so it is like it has just been initialised.

      • preToRemovingElement

        protected void preToRemovingElement(T element)

      • preToReplacingElement

        protected void preToReplacingElement(T oldElement)

      • actuallyAddElement

        protected T actuallyAddElement(Emitter<T> emitter)
        1) Call emitter.emitParticle. 2) Add emitted element to internal list(s). 3) Set emitted element state to MAIN_LIFE_STAGE.
        Returns:
        The added element.

      • actuallyAddElementWithID

        protected void actuallyAddElementWithID(int ID,
                                        Emitter<T> emitter)

      • actuallyAddElementWithPointer

        protected void actuallyAddElementWithPointer(Pointer<T> pointer,
                                             Emitter<T> emitter)

      • actuallyRemoveElement

        protected void actuallyRemoveElement(T element)
        1) Null pointers and deregister all IDs registered with element. 2) Remove element from internal list(s). 3) Set element state to REMOVED (so in dispose know that have been removed, not replaced). 4) Call element.dispose().

      • actuallyReplaceElement

        protected void actuallyReplaceElement(T oldElement,
                                      Emitter<T> newEmitter)
        1) Call emitter.emitParticle. 2) Re-point pointers and reassign IDs. 3) Remove oldElement from internal list(s). 4) Add emitted element to internal list(s). 5) Set oldElement state to REPLACED (so in dispose know that have been replaced, not removed). 6) Call oldElement.dispose() (the element replacing oldElement should be the only one in the list that is in the PRE_CREATION state). 7) Set emitted element state to MAIN_LIFE_STAGE.

      • failIfIDInvalid

        protected void failIfIDInvalid(int ID)

      • internalRegisterID

        protected void internalRegisterID(int ID,
                                  T element)

      • internalAddWithID

        protected void internalAddWithID(int ID,
                                 Emitter<T> emitter)

      • flushChanges

        protected void flushChanges()
        Called when number of locks falls to 0. This is an example of "when main changes applied": - Changes from addElement, removeElement, and replaceElement take place. - Order that particles were asked to be added, removed, etc. is followed.

      • isInstantaneousChanges

        protected boolean isInstantaneousChanges()

      • actuallyAddToInternalLists

        protected abstract void actuallyAddToInternalLists(T element)
        Just add element to internal list(s) - don't change life cycle state or anything like that.

      • actuallyRemoveFromInternalLists

        protected abstract void actuallyRemoveFromInternalLists(T element)
        Just remove element from internal list(s) - don't change life cycle state or anything like that.
